A new French daily morning paper, "Les Nouvelles," made its appearance at Atexandria to-day under: the editorship of M. George Dumani, a journalist of experience, whom we welcome among"us here and wish every success,
The Holy Carpet.

The Ministry of the Interior received a tele- grax yesterday from the Emir el Hag in the Hedjaz, stating that the Holy Carpet and its escort had arrived at Medina on the 26th ulto. and they are returning vid Jeddah, where they are dne on the 11th inst. The pilgrims at Medina are all in o satisfactory state of health.
Rudolph.

The report of the committee of the Asile Rudolph, Alexandria, shows that the good work undertaken at that in-titution increases in, scope year by year. During last year, 200,060 rations were distributed among' the poor, a8 against 179,641 in 1905, 82,460 in 1904, 101,600 in 1903, 107,000 in 1902, and 98,800 in 1901. Refuge was given during the year to 9,125 persons, as against 5,110 in 1905, 7,408 in. 1904, 6,052 in 1903, 6,800 in 1902, and 4245 in 1901. The receipts of the asile during the year amounted to P.T. 144,048, as against P.T. 112,385 in: 1905, and the expenditare to P.T. 129,905, as against P.T. 119 280. The committee express their gratitude and thanks for all the assistance they have received in the shape of subscriptions and gifts in kind, and appeal for a continuance of this support, which is necessary owing to the increasing demands on the asile. The instit.tion is strictly in- ternational, aud no distinction of sect is made,

div.head: CAIRO BILLIARD TOURNAMENT.
div.p: On Friday evening the first round of the Cairo billiard markers' tournament was play- ed at Shepheard's Hotel, the players, as usual, being Percy, of Shepheard's Syer, of the Con- tinental, and Flowers, of Ghezireh Palace, while the Handicap was as follows :—Syer, scratch, Perpy receives 50, Flowers receives 76. Play-commenced at exactly 9.30 p.m. by Syer playing a safety miss into back against Percy, but the latter scored a very neat cannon, Which resulted in a useful start of 19. At his fourth visit to the table Syer put together an excellent 47, the fourth stroke being an éx- ceedingly pretty cannon off a double baulk, and following this with 16 he passed Percy's total, the scores at this point being 78-70. The next break of note was made by Percy, who compiled a useful 40, but shortly afterwards Syer made another break of 44, which consist- ed of nursery cannons. This indeed was the best break of the evening and Syer nursed the balls with great skill. Play continued fairly level for a while, Syer being responsible for a good 20, but Percy followed this with 23 and 20, and having previously compiled smaller, but none the less useful breaks, obtained a lead which proved too much for Cairo's winner of last year. A thirty-two, almost entirely from the middle pocket, brought Syer within measurable distance of his opponent, but after this break he,did nothing, the balls running rather badly for him, and Percy kept well ahead, winning eventually by 74, the game of 300 up having lasted an hour and seven minutes. The second, and final, game of the round, was between Percy and Flowers, the score commencing according to the handicap at 50- 75. At his fourth visit Flowers put togéther 20, all his scores comin from cannons and losing hazards off the white, and alter a series of visits which resulted in nothing of note Perey compiled 28. For most of the time Flowers maintained a goodd lead, but neither player scored well for some time, until close on the second hundred, when Percy made a break of 31, and this gave him the lead. After a series of indifferent breaks, in which Percy had slightly the better of it, the latter finally ran out with a very pretty thirty break, thus winning both games from his-table. The next round will be played chez Flowers at Ghezireh Palace on Tuésday evening.

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
div.p: RESOLUTIONS DEPRECATED.

We understand that the representatives of the Coptic community of Egypt have forward- ed a petition to Lord Cromer in which they express their confidence in the general admi- istration of the country and deprecate the constitutional changes proposed by the General Assembly.

The following is the text of a letter addressed to Lord Cromer by the British Chamber of Commerce dated 9th March, 1907 : My Lord, I have the honour to inform your Lordship that my Committee having heard withh feelings of distinct apprehension that the Egyptian General Assembly, at their recent meeting, had passed a resolution in favour of the establishment of an Egyptian Purliament having control of the finances of the country, a special meeting of the Chamber was called on the 7th inst., to consider the question. After discussion, my Committee unanimosly passed the following resolution, which I venture to ask your Lordship to kindly trans- mit to His Majesty's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs :

"The Committee of the British Chamber of Commerce has read with great regret and concern the recent accounts in the press of the resolution. passed by the Egyptian General. Assembly for the establishment of an Egyptian parliament having control of the finances of the coun- try, simaltaneously with agitations in the British Parliament for an enquiry into the Egyptian system of administration. "And would reapectfully urge on His Majesty's Government that any steps that would tend to materially change the existing system of administration of the country would be premature, and fatal to the best interests of all c'asses in Egypt, both Native and European, and while grievously impeding the great and growing commerce of the country, would be a serious blow to her moral and financial prosperity"
I would mention that the Cairo Committee of this Chamber fully endorses the above reso- lution.
I have the honour to be, etc., (Signed) H.P Kiyonan, Presideut
THEe KHEDIVE.
The Khedive came down to Alexandria from Cairo on Saturday evening and proceeded yesterday to Mariout, where he will inspect his estates,

div.head: IBRAHIMIEH GREEK SCHOOL.
div.p: The ceremony of laying the foundation stone of the Aristotelis Prazzica Greek School at Ibrahimieh took place on Saturday afternoon. Owing to the great number of Greeks resident at Ibrahimieh a special Hellenic community was founded there in 1904 under the presid- ency of Mr. Aristotelis Prazzica, of Epirus, and Mr. Xenophon Joatmidis, of Cyprus, vice- president. These two gentleman last year gave £1,000 and £2,000 for a new Greek school and a new Greek church respectively. At shortly after 5 o'clock on Saturday afternoon the foundation stone of the new Prazzica School was laid by Mrs.Eliza Prazzica. Some current: coins and a copy of the "Egyptian Gazette" and the "Tachydromos" of that date were placed in the cavity. 'Ihe religious cere- monial was conducted by Monsignor Theofanis Moschonas, the Metropolitan of ripoli, and the vicar representing the Patriarch, in the presence of Mr. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul- General, Mr. Benachi, president of the Hellenic community of Alexandria, and Mrs. Benachi, Mr, and Mrs. Salvago, Mr. George Zervudachi, Mr. Ambroise Zervudachi, Mr, and Mrs. Xenophon Joannidis, Mr. Joannidis, manager of the Bank of Athens, Mr. Demosthene Tambacopoulo, maziager of the Orient Bank, Mr. Paleologo Georgiu, headmaster of the Alexandria Greek Schools with his professional staff and the pupils, Mrs. Stampa, head- mistress of the Averoff girls' school,and a large crowd of the Hellenic magnates and granders or Alexandria. Afier the stone -had been laid Mr. Paleologo Georgin made an eloquent speech on the history of the Greek community at Ibrahimieh and delivered a eulogy on the philanthropic aims of Messrs. Aristotelis Prazzica and: Xendphon Joannidis. He concluded by expressing the hope that all patriotic Greeks in Egypt would imitate the splendid exaniple of these gentlemen in endeavouring to spread the knowledge of the Greek tongue in Egypt. The Consul General replied and Mr. Aristotelis Prazzica concluded this in- teresting ceremony by a warm speech of thanks on behalf of Mr. Joannidis and himself forthe good wishes they had received. He declared that they were most happy that their ambitions had been realised. and asserted that these were only their preliminary endowments, An adjournment was then made to the buffet, where a bounteous repast was partaken, of.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY
div.p: GENERAL MEETING IN LONDON.
(Garette'a Special Service)
London, Saturday.

The annual general meeting of the New Egyptian Company, Limited, was held in London yesterday. The accounts submitted showed a profit for the year of £25,885, butin view of the-company's engagements and the general financial position of Egypt the board did not recommend any distrbiition of dividend. The chairman madé a full statement showing the progress of the company's reclamation works, stating that the other land and share assets of the company had increased in value. He further stated that if the negotia- tions now pending for the sale of one of the company's properties were successful a sub- stantial interim dividend would be at once paid. The shareholders unanimously adopted the report and accounts and approved the policy of the board. The meeting waa well attended.

div.head: EXCELSIOR HOTELS COMPANY
div.p: The option given to the Egyptian Improve- ments Corporation by the Excelsior Hotels Company for the pruchase of the property of that company in Place Soliman Pasha at Cairo expired on Saturday. As the negotia- tions for the formation of a new: company to take over this land for building have not succeeded the Excelsior Hotels Company has prolonged the option until the 23rd inst. If, however, during that time the Excelsior Hotels receive a more profitable offer, the option is to be changed into a preferential right valid for 48 hours.

div.head: UNITED HOTELS OF - EGYPT.
div.p: We would draw the attention of our readers to the issue of shares in the United Hotels of Egypt (Limited).

The company has been formed for the establishment and exploitation of first-class hotels in the variotly towns, and villages of Egypt not already provided therewith. It is well[-]known that beyond Cairo, Alexandria, and their suburbs, Luxor and Assousn, there do not exist many if any first-class hotels in the other towns of Egypt. The population of the latter towns has greatly increased during the past few years and the need for the estab- lishnitnt of good hotels in such centres is greatly felt. The company proposes, in the first instance, to erect and carry on first-class hotels in the' Fayoum, Tantah, Mansourab, Zagazig, and Minieh, in short five of the most important and flourishing business'or agricul- tural centiés in Egypt The Fayoum, which is visited yearly by numerous tourists, would probably be patronised by many more visitors if a good hotel were erected, but they are deterred at present from going there owing to the disadvantages and expense of living under canvas. Now that the railway service with the Fayoum has been improved the Fayoum should upon the opening of a hotel Of the company become a popular resort for residents in Cairo anxious to get a change of air and scene.

We understand that the companys' first operation in the purchase of a plot of land in one of the principal towns of the interior, has been most successful, as they have already been offered double the price paid for the lad. If this offer were accepted it would leave the company in the position of having the re- mainder of the land-on which the hotel is to be built for nothing

The subscription list will remain open at the Bank of Athens, Cairo and. Alexandria, until Tuesday evening in order to give time to the subscribers in the Interior and Upper Egypt to send in-their application forms, 'as the prospectuses were only sent out to the Interior on Friday.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL: MAIL LINE
div.p: We are informed that the accounts of this company show that at the end of January the receipts exceeded by £41,000 those at the corresponding period of last year; which were the highest since the formation of the com- pany.

div.head: SUDAN LAND DEVELOPMENT
div.p: MR. MACGILLIVRAY'S INTERESTS.

By the purchase of the major interests in al Mr. Leigh Hunt's estate in the Sudan, Mr. de D.P. MacGillivray, late Governor of the Bank G of Abyssinia, has joined Mr. Hunt in the B active control of the property. It will be P. remembered that in 1904 a concession was M granted to Mr. Leigh Hunt by the Sudan Government. This is embodied in the report of the Committee on Government Land in the M Sadan published in June of that year. An idea of the importance of the concession uay be formed when it is remembered that Mr. Leigh Hunt was granted summer hunting rights for 4,000 feddans out of the 10,000 feddans allotted to the whole Sudan in respect : these rights.

div.head: SAVOY DANCE.
div.p: LARGE ATTENDANCE OP DANCERS.

Pessimists are already declaring the season to be on the wane, but statistics show no diminution of numbers at the moment and the disney at the Savoy on Saturday was as well attended as any we have remembered this Brason: It was really the first warm evening of the year, but thanks to the ladies' orchestra at which kept trust excellent time it was possible to enjoy the dances, without undue exertion. I was the last dance of the season for a goodM hany present, as various of the most popular |H. balles are leaving Egypt next week; and indeed of The near approach of an early Easter is causing Ide many people to consider their dates of de thu bart re. The tennis tournament bas attracted fair number of folk from Alexandria this keek; and most of them were present at Satur Hay's dance, Mr. Hope Percival and Mr. and Li Miss Alderson being among those whose visits Cairo are of a more or less flying character.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demi.) Nous devons signaler de nouvelles tentatives pour garer la spéculation dans le fouillis les nouvelles émissions ; mais ces marceuvres ne réussissent pas, comme l'atteste l'insuccès éclatant de quelques souscriptions r centes. Le résultat est qu'on est plus calme sur les mos titres, tandis qu'on pousse quelques papiers frais pondus de façon plus ou moins Tactique.

Ajoutons, pour être exact, que nous n'englobons pas toutes les valeurs nouvelles dans la 19 hume catégorie ; quelques-unes, point trop poussées, peuvent offrir quelques avantages ; mais, de façon générale, la plus grande circonspection est à recommander sur ce chapitre.
L'agricole est un peu plus faible 9 1/8, la Delta Light A 11 8 16, la Land Bank a 8 18/16 Ge et 1 Union Fonciere 6.
Parmi les petites valeurs, l'Investment cote 1,5/92, les Estates 2 1/4 et la Port Said Salt M 18/9. L'Arditi est demandée à 15 82 l'action da et 24 la fondatrice.
Il y a en du mouvement sur presque toute la route et les acheteurs des prix bas ne manquent pas. Aussi ne tarderons-nous pas à voir une amélioration.

div.head:
THE NAVY
NOT TO BE WEAKENED.

div.p: Lord Tweedmouth, speaking at Oxford said that it was not true that the Government contemplated weakening the Navy, which they realised must be strong enough to serve it purpose whatever it cost, but they would 8 to The Hague Conference, with a full thesis for the reduction of armaments. If the other Powers-did not meet us they 'must take the responsibility. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE INDIAN COMMAND.
DUKE OF CONNAUGHT MENTIONED

div.p: The Daily Telegraph" announces that the Duke of Connaught will probably be asked to accept the command of the forces in India when Lord Kitchener retires. It is hoped that General French will become Chief of the General Staff at the War Office. (Reuter)

div.head:
"LA VILLE LUMIERE."
END OF ELECTRICIANS' STRIKE,

div.p: The theatres continue to close. The electricians have decided to return to work to-day: (Haras)
Light reappeared at midnight. (Havas)
The electric light strike; is ended. The city has resumed its normal evening aspect. Theatres are open and papers appearing again, (Reuter)
The police has posted up a notice warning people that any further meeting at the University will be dispersed by force if strangers to the establishment take part. (Havas)

div.head:
THE CONSTANTINOPLE QUAYS.
PURCHASE DISQUIETS GERMANS.

div.p: The Anglo-French purchase of the quay has disquieted German circles here, who feel that their long commercial monopoly in Turkey is threatened. It transpires that German financo unsuccessfully endeavoured to forestal the purchase. • (Reuter)

The Colonial vote, the rejection of which caused the dissolution in December, passed the second reading without a debate. The minority again consisted of the Centre, the Poles, and the Socişlists. (Reuter)
. Mr. Bryce will visit Ottawa in April in order to discuss with Earl Grey and Sir W. Laurier matters regarding the Dominion of Canada and the United States. , (Reuter)
The deaths are announced of the self-styled prophet Dowie and Admiral Sir Richard Tracey. (Reuter)
Football. Rugby. Wales beat Ireland by 29 points to nil. (Renter)

div.head:
HOUSE OF LORDS.
"AN INSULT TO THE COMMUNITY."

div.p: Mr. Winston Churchill, in an article in the "Nation," suggests that the House of Lord should be constituted of from 180 to 250 members of the Privy Council and Peers, to be summoned by the Crown on the advice of Ministers for a term of one Parliament, the other Peers being eligible for election to the House of Commons. Mr. Lloyd George, speaking at Nottingham said that the country would be asked before long to deal with the Lords, and in no uncertain manner. If it was necessary to have a second chamber let it be composed of men and intelligence. The present chamber was an insult to the community. (Reuter)
A crowded indignation meeting of suffragettes was held at Exeter Hall last night. I was resolved. to censure the Government attitude and to urge women to unite with the Opposition. (Reuter)

The Socialists in the Duma are determined to force the political amnesty question to it issue. The Moderates are already threatening dissolution if the Socialists persist in their intransigent attitude. (Reuter)
Two vice-presidents and five secretaries of the Duma belong to the Left. (Havas)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lieutenants E. Longueville, C.K. Hutchison, R.L. Dawson, G. Stewart, and W M. Beckwith, Coldstream Guards, have been promoted captains. Captains Dawson and Beckwith are with the 3rd Battalion, Cairo;, and Captain Stewart is attached to the Egyptian Army. The first-named three joined the Coldstreamers in 1898, and Captain Stewart got his commission in 1899. All saw service 'in the South African War, for which they are decorated.

The Army Council has decided to withdraw the one-pounder quick-firing gun -- popularly known as the "pom-pom" - from cavalry regiments and mounted infantry. The gun and its equipments are to be handed over to local officers in charge of Ordnance. It may be recalled that thiş gun came into prominence during the Boer War, and its reputation as a weapon was due more to its infernal and nerve shaking "pom-pom" than to its actual kill and wounding effects

The vacant company in the King's Royal Rifle Corps has been filled by the promotion of Lieutenant R. F. Dalrymple, the senior subal. tern, presently serving with the 1st Battalion in Egypt. Captain Dalrymple had to serve seven and a half years for his step He was a mounted infantry officer in the South African War, and saw a good deal of hard work in the fighting on the way to Ladysmith, and in the guerilla warfare of the succeeding operations (Queen's medal with five clasps, and King's inedal with two clasps).

div.head: S. & S. F. A.
div.p: REPORT FOR 1906.

The following is an extract from the Seerd | the military's report of the Soldiers' and Sailor Families' Association (Alexandria Branch) fo 1906 :| During the year, the scheme suggested last February, for starting a Narsingi Branch, hal been carried out, and so far has worked most successfully. The head office in London me us in every possible way, and promised to subscribe £50 annually to the Nursing Fund, in addition to paying the nurse's passage both ways. They kindly engaged Nurse Wraxa for us, on a term of three years at a salary of £40 for the first year, with an annual increase of £5" In order to comply with their regulations, we have been obliged to keep Nursing Fund separate from the general ac corint, which, as you will remember, was no our first intention. For this purpose we too the balance of the Clothing Fund (£35.17.4. to form a nucleus. To avoid the complication of two separate lists, it is thought best, in asking for subscriptions, not to specify either fun particularly, but to pay the money according to the Treasurer's discretion, to whichever i most in leed at the moment, unless the subscriber should have expressed any special wis in the matter. Arrangements with the head office were completed as quickly as possible and on May 25th Miss Wiaxall arrived from | England. I am glad to be able to report her work has been most satisfactory. Up t the end of the year, the record shows 184 case of illness, and 2124 visits paid. Locally, the scheme has met with every encouragement Messrs: Moss & Co. very kindly offered to bring out our nurse at a 10% reduction of their ordinary fare, and although on this once sion arrangements had already been made i England for her journey, we may be very glad to avail ourselves of this in the future. Alexandria and Ramleh Railway have generously given her a free pass on their ling which of course makes a great reduction in travel expenses.

Through the courtesy of the Victoria House Committee Miss Wraxall has been accommodated with a room there, which has proved very convenient arrangement. The thanks 'the committee are also due to Major Downin and other friends, who arranged an entertainment in November, in aid of the Branch fund: They took the Tour Eiffel Music Hall i Alexandria, and secured the services of the various artistes, whose ordinary program was slightly "Bowdlerized" and supplemented | by an assault-åt-arms, kindly given by the members and instructors of the Pencin Club. The band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers played during the intervals by kind perfdildian of Colonel ophall and the officers. The ball was crowded and the entertainment was most successful. Besides the £84.18.11 shown in the balance sheets, there is still I believe, an additional £2 of £8 to be paid in when all expenses have been settled We are further indebted to the Royal Dublin Fusiliers for an excellent doneert which they gave in the Army Temperance Association room in December, as a result of which Mr. French has handed me £15.17.4. On reference to the accounts, you will notice that, whereas in 1905 the subscriptions amounted to £21.1 3, in 1906 they have been raised to £92.12.4. Besides this, the two entertainments referred to produced a total of £100.16 8, which, with the London subscription of £50, makes a grand total of £248 8,7. You will also notice that on the 1st January, 1906, we had in the two funds £107.8.6. On the 1st January, 1907, we show a balance of £257.6.8. This is of course most satisfactory, but I should like to point out that for several reasons the past year cannot be taken as a criterion. "Firstly, the nurse did not arrive till the end of May, and therefore another year, the expenses of her Jupkeep are likely to be about £160 instead of £80. Secondly, is the money from the entertainments did not come in till December, I was not at all certain, earlier in the year, of the strength of our financial position, and therefore did not feel justified in administering the funds with anything but the most rigid economy, More money could, with great advantage have been spent on various cases brought to my notice, had I been sure that I had it to spend. Again, much of the money came in the form of donations, and although it is to be hoped that we shall meet with the same generosity this year, we cannot absolutely count upon it. Also the two entertainments provided more than 2/5ths of last year's income, and although our friends may be ready to help us again, I am afraid we cannot always count on such brilliant successes...
List of Subscriptions and Donations for the year ended 31st December 1906:-

div.head: AUFGEBOT
div.p: Es wird hiermit bekannt gemacht, dass die Schweizer Bürger und deutsche Schutz Genoss Gustav Adolf Grob seines Standes Maschinen meister geboren in Wattwil Kanton St. Gallen 82 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Kafr Danouhit Zagazi, Sohn des in Wil wohnhaften 66 Jahre alten Conditors Karl Grob und dessen in Zürich wohnhaften 77 Jahre alten Ehefrau Berta geborenen Landolt, Lund die Schweizer Bürgerin und deutsche Schutz|| genossin Anne Stärk geboren in Zürich, 25 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Zürich Tochter des in Zürich im Alter von 64 Jahren verstorbener Droschken Halters Johannes Stärk und dessert gleichfalls im Alter von 45 in Zürich verstorbenen Ehefrau Bertha geborene Zellweger beabsichtigen sich mit einander zu verehelicher und diese Ehe in Gemäßheit des Reichsgesetzes vom 4. Mai 1870 vor dem unterzeichneten Beamten abzuschließen. Alexandrien, den 8. März 1909. - Der Kaiserliche Konsul. Gez: WUNDERLICH. 29747-1

div.head: The Choir Boy. Who was wasting Away. · Slokly, Languld Boyhood. Always Falling and Nervous. Changed Into A Healthy Boy By DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.
div.p: With a bright, intelligent face, and a voice sweet and full, little George Thorne Harris is well known to the congregation of St. Paul's Church, Birmingham. As he stands in the choir in his spotless surplice, one would imagine that physical suffering is unknown to him Yet-and it is testimony to the wonder ful changes that are wrought in debilitated systems by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People there was a time when this bright boy was "always ailing." Speaking of her son the other day, bis mother who lives at 180; Bridge-street West, Birmingham, said: "People will hardly believe lit, but before George took Dr. Williams' Pink Pills his cheeks were pale and drawn; he was always so languid and sleepy that only with the greatest difficulty could I get him to school. He constantly suffered from sick headaches, so THESE WERE made little progress in school MIS SYMPTOMS. work, but would return home feeling dull, baby and bilious. His sleep at þight was broken and restless, and often, he woke up startled from dreams and bathed in perspiration. A persistent hacking cough shook bis frame terribly, so much so that his nerves seemed to become quite upset. All desire for games left him, he lost his appetite entirely, und as he lost in weight so his vitality was reduced. We tried to tempt him with all sorts bf morsels, but quite in vain. He would always eat it to-morrow, mother.' | "I became greatly concerned about him, especially when having tried all sorts of medicines, we could see no improvement in the boy: As the illness gained a hold on him he wasted away under my eyes, until he became a lifeless, pale, emaciated fig res. "At length, almost in despair, I decided to try Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, as I had derived great benefit from these pills. = After he had taken the pills for some little time there was a marked change He began T to enjoy sleep soundly, 'and his appetite was as sharp as that of a healthy boy. We could see such an improvement in him following the use of Dr Williams' Pink Pills that in a few weeks we had the satisfaction of seeing him well and strong, and the life and soul of the school. It was on his restoration to health that the latent powers of his voice were brought out, And he joined the church choir of St. Paul's, where he has remained ever since." If proof were needed that George Thorne su Harris is now strong, with sound lungs, it is to be found in the fact that last September he gains. ed a prize for swimming, and when the reporter saw him he was the picture of health and 1 boyish vitality, a great contrast to his state of health before taking Dr Williams' Pink Pills To Deficient of Vitality, Weak, Nervous, Always Ailing -all these troubles in both sexos arise from poor and bad blood. div.p: This Propsectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies
The Subscription list will be open for one day only, vis, the 16th day of March 1907, at the Company's Bankers, The Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmic
Cairo and Alexandria.
THE AUTO-GARAGE AND AUTO-CABS Company Limited.
(Incorporated under the Companies'. Aots, 1862 to 1900.)
DIVIDED INTO 5625 Ordinary Shares of £4 each = £22,500
AND 5000*Founder Shares of 11- each = £ 250/$22,750

According to the Company's Memorandum of Association, the profits of the Company of each financial year which shall remain after setting aside a sum equal to 7 per cent. of the value of the Company's plant or such larger amount as the Company may think necessary foi providing for the renewal and augmentation of the Company's plant are applicable as follows:
First. To the payment of a cumulative preferential dividend at the rate of 6 per cent per annum on the Capital for the time being paid up on the ordinary shares to the close of such year.
Secondly. Five per cent thereof is to be carried to the Company's general reserve fund
Thirdly. Of the residue of such balance 10 per cent. is to be divided between the Directors as additional remuneration for their services.

Fourthly. Of the surplus of such residue 50 per cent. is applicable to the payment of & further dividend on the Ordinary Shares in proportion to the. Capital paid up thereon and 50 per cent is applicable to the payment of dividend on the Founders Shares in proportion to the capital paid up thereon
In a winding up of the Company the Assets distributable amongst the members are ta be applied.
First, In paying off the capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares and all arrears of the cumulative dividend thereon whether declared or not to the commencement of the winding up

Secondly. Or the balance 50 per cent is to be distributed amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares in proportion to the Ordinary Shares held by them respectively and the other 50 per cent is to be distributed amongst the holders of the Founders Shares in proportion to the Founders Shares held by them respectively.

1875 Ordinary Shares are now offered for subscription at par: payable 10/- per share on application y allotment and the balance in three instalments of £1.- each at intervals of not less than two months from each other. Any subscriber for ordinary shares aforesaid who receives an allotment will have a right to subscribe at par for one Founders share in respect of every 10 of the said Ordinary Share allotted to such subscriber. Share Warı ants to Bearer will be issued after full payment of the shares.
Founders shares shall be fully paid in Allotment
Directors

H.H. PRINCE AZIZ PACHA HASSAN, Gentleman of independent means, Shared Shubra, Cairo, THEODORE- NICOLAS CORESSY KORESSIOS, Engineer-Contractor, Shareh Magrabi, Cairo EMILE MANUSARDI, Advocate, Shareh Magrabi, Cairo, JOSEPH SAMI GALI, Proprietor, Shareh Magrabi, Cairo ETTORE BUCCIANTI, Stockbroker, 2, Shareh El-Bank ET-Watang, Cairo. NEGHIB CHAKOUR BEY, Advocate, Rue du Tél, phone, Cairo.
General Manager.
CHRISTOS LOUKAITIS.

Secretary and tRegistered Office. W. A. WATERLOW, 25 Birchin Lane, London E. O.
PROSPECTUS.

This Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in its Memorandum of Association and in particular to manufacture, deal in, sell and let on hire motor cars and motor cabs and also to acquire and take over from the Vendor a9 & going concern the garage business carried on at Cairo by Mr. Christos Loukaitis. ..
The Company will have a spacious garage and workshops well furnished with tools for the repair, manufacture and alteration of motor cars

The Vendor Mr. Loukaitis has been appointed General Manager of the Company for a period of five years from the incorporation of the Company at a salary of £600 per annum and he is bound not to engage in any business in Egypt of a nature calculated to compete with that of the Company.

The property included in the sale comprises the. Vendor's business, hig garage at Cairo held on lease for an unexpired term of five years (dating from 20th March 1906) at the moderate annual rental of £180 and the full benefit of all pending contracts and engagements and subject to all pending trade contracts and engagements.

The purchase price has been fixed at £2500 or such legs sum as shall be certified by two valuers one to be appointed by the Vendor and the other by the Company or their umpire to be the true value of the property to be sold.
The whole of the purchase price viz: £2000 will be satisfied by the allotment to the Vendors or his nominees of 625 fully paid up ordinary shares of £4 each in the Capital of the Company.

The balance of 5000 Ordinary Shares after deduction of the 625 which are to be issued as fully paid to the Vendor, has been underwritten by the Directors including the Vendor in the following proportions: H. H. Prince Aziz Pacha Hassan 4/60 tbs., Mr. T. N. Koressios 10/60ths., Mr. E. Manusardi 7/50ths., MrJS Gali 7/50ths., Mr. E. Buccianti 47/60ths., UrN. Chakour Bey 5'50ths. and Mr. C Loukaitis 10 50ths.

Of the 5000 Founders shares, 500 are reserved for allotment to subgèribers for ordinary shares in the proportion of one Founders share for every ten ordinary shares and the remainder 29,000 Founders shares are to be divided between the Founders of the Company and the Vendor, according to the Agreement dated 13th June 1906 and this as remuneration for the underwriting of the above 5000 Ordinary Shares
The minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 10 percent of the shares offered.

The Contract for the sale of the business is dated the 1st August 1906, and made between the said Christus Loukaitis of the last part, all the above named Directors and the said Christos Loukaitis of the 2nd vart and Nechib Ayoub of Cairo As Trustee for the Company (then about to be registered) of the 3rd part

The above mentioned tuo contracts have been adopted by a further contract dated the 7th February 1907 and made between Theodor Nicolas Coresgy-Koression and Emile Manusard of Cairo both Directors of and on behalf of the Company of the 1st part and Christos Loukalt of Cairo being the vendor of the 2d part and Neghib Ayoub, Advocate of Cairo as trustee foi the Company of the 3rd part.

The Articles of Association provide that the qualification of every Director is to be the holding of shares or Stock of the Company of the nominal value of £ 200 and that a first Director may act before acquiring his qualification.

The Articles of Association also provide that the Directors shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration for their services the percentage of profits specified in the Company's Memorandum of Association and such further sums as shall from time to time be determined by the Company in General Meeting and that such percentage of profits and further sums (if any) shall be divided among them in bunch proportions and manner' as the Directors by agreement may determine and in default of such determination equally. They also provide that the remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be Axed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting ang may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits or by any or all of these methods and they also provide that if any Director being willing shall be called upon to perform extra services or to take any special exertions in going or residing abroad or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate such Director either by a fixed pum or by a percentage of profits or otherwise as naay be determined by the Directors and such remuneration may be dither in addition to or in substitution to his share in the remuneration as herein before stated.
The preliminary expenses up to allotment for the incorporation of the Company are estimated at £600, the stamp duty is included in this amount and payable by the Company.
for Copies of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and of the above mentioned Contracts can be inspected at the Company's Office in Cairo at any time during business hours. is
A Copy of the Company's Memorandum of Association is printed on the back of this prospectus and forms part of it.

Application for shares should be made upon the form accompanying the prospectus and sent to the Company Bankers, the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio Cairo and Alexandria, together with a remittance for the amount of the deposit. Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in full and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments Failure to pay any future instalment on shares allotted when due will render previous payments liable to forfeiture
Prospectus and Forms of Application can be obtained at the Company's Office in Cairo and Alexandria. Dated Ciiro the 23rd day of February 1907.

Le montant då en raison de cet appel devra être versé aux banquiers de la société, d'ici à vendredi 16 mars 1907, dernier délai: À Londres, chez M.M. Barclay & Co. Ltd., 64, Lombard Street, .O.; ag Caire et à Alexandrie, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd.

Le cahier des auberges est déposé au barreau de Nettoiement ou il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 19 Mai 1907.
Bites pourront également être déposées er Bőance de la Délégation le même jour å 5 b.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour fourniture des balais."

Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur
(Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY. Alexandrie, lo 6 Mara 1907. 29724 8 8

Le cautionnement est fixé A LE. 60 (801 zante).
Le caviar d'où charge est déposé an barena Tecbı iqne où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 b. à midi, lego Gars fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 25 Mars 1907.
Filles pourront également être déposées en Béanog de la Délégation lo même jour à Bh. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour travaux d'asphaltage lane partie de la Rue Rossetto."

REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
